pullRequest.body:
Add theorems giving a clique in the supergraph if there is a clique in a subgraph induced by a superset of the clique, as well as theorems about independent sets in induced subgraphs on G.

---
I needed these theorems for a proof about Ramsey numbers. Maybe it would be interesting to have in the `mathlib`?

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:

- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

> I needed these theorems for a proof about Ramsey numbers. Maybe it would be interesting to have in the `mathlib`?

What proof? I assume you're aware of @b-mehta's formalisation of Ramsey numbers? Just making sure you're not duplicating effort, there's enough to do like this ðŸ˜‰

### PR summary [b8b04d349d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20705/commits/b8b04d349d5e491aa63d1829e3c93440f7421430)

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> > I needed these theorems for a proof about Ramsey numbers. Maybe it would be interesting to have in the `mathlib`?
> 
> What proof? I assume you're aware of @b-mehta's formalisation of Ramsey numbers? Just making sure you're not duplicating effort, there's enough to do like this ðŸ˜‰

Thanks for the pointer! :) I am aware of a [`lean3` project of b-metha](https://github.com/b-mehta/exponential-ramsey/blob/main/src/main_results.lean) concerning ramsey numbers, where they also prove results I prove. My goal was to formalize the proof from [THE BOOK](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proofs_from_THE_BOOK) in `lean4` as literally as feasible, mostly for educational purposes.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks!

maintainer merge

Thanks for your PR!

Looks good to me in general, I left some small remarks. Also note that this is the first time I'm reviewing something for mathlib, so chances are someone more knowledgeable will have some more feedback later:)
Thank you for the PR, and you Pim for the review! Here are a few more comments.

Thanks!

maintainer delegate

Thanks!

maintainer merge

Depending on what you need it for it might also make sense to use `coeSpanning` instead along with an hypothesis of the form `(h : A âŠ† F)`. I think this is also fine, it just depends on your usecase. Also holds for the other lemma's.

Do you mean something like this?
```
theorem spanning_isClique {S : Subgraph G} {A : Set S.verts} (c : S.spanningCoe.IsClique A) :
    G.IsClique (Subtype.val '' A) := by
```
I could also add those, if that's a use case that's expected to come up. The induced subgraph way perfect for my situation :)

I meant something along these lines (but yours is also a valid alternative):

```
theorem induce_isClique {S : Subgraph G} {F A : Set Î±} (h : A âŠ† F)  (c : (S.induce F).spanningCoe.IsClique A)  : 
    G.IsClique A := by sorry
```

In any case, if you don't need either of these I'd personally say to just leave it at this until we do, but I'm happy to be overruled by someone with a better big picture overview:)

If simp(_all) is not the tactic that closes the goal, you'll want to squeeze the simp (in this case by using the output from `simp_all?`). This ensures that the rest of the proof remains valid if more simp lemma's are added in the future. Also holds for the other lemmas except `induce_isIndepSet_iff`, because there it is the final call.
I did what I suspect you mean by "squeezing", namely only using `simp(_all) only` for non-clonsing `simp`. Is that correct? ðŸ˜…
Yep, looks good to me:)

```suggestion
  exact fun _ â†¦ induce_isIndepSet_iff G
```
Just a small golf

```suggestion
  exact S.adj_sub (c ainA binA (Subtype.coe_ne_coe.mp anb)).2.2
```

Small golf

```suggestion
    G.IsNClique n (Finset.map âŸ¨Subtype.val, Subtype.val_injectiveâŸ© s) := by
  rw [isNClique_iff] at cc âŠ¢
  simp only [Subgraph.induce_verts, coe_map, card_map]
  exact âŸ¨induce_isClique cc.left, cc.rightâŸ©
```

* Head functions should come first in the lemma name, unless they are postfix notation (dot notation isn't considered postfix notation)
* `_iff` and `_eq` should be dropped unless necessary for disambiguation
```suggestion
theorem isIndepSet_induce {F : Set Î±} {s : Set F} :
    ((âŠ¤ : Subgraph G).induce F).coe.IsIndepSet s â†” G.IsIndepSet (Subtype.val '' s) := by
```

Similarly,
```suggestion
theorem isNIndepSet_induce {F : Set Î±} {s : Finset { x // x âˆˆ F }} {n : â„•} :
```

```suggestion
 its embedding is an `n`-clique in `G`. -/
```

I would expect something like this to work
```suggestion
  simp [isNIndepSet_iff, induce_isIndepSet_iff]
```

I would expect the same, but there is something really odd happening. your suggestion of 
`simp [isNIndepSet_iff, isIndepSet_induce]`
cannot prove the goal, but
` simp [isNIndepSet_iff, (isIndepSet_induce)]`
can! I did not believe my eyes, but the ci build seems to agree with me (see the latest two commits). I am now very confused.
Wait! Did you see this @YaelDillies ? Isn't there some kind of problem here?

There's no assumption, so `simp_all` is useless:
```suggestion
  simp [Set.Pairwise]
```
or possibly
```suggestion
  simp +contextual [Set.Pairwise]
```

```suggestion
 its embedding is a clique in `G`. -/
```

What is this coercion doing? Is it not the identity?
```suggestion
    (cc : (S.induce F).coe.IsNClique n s) :
```

```suggestion
theorem IsClique.of_induce {S : Subgraph G} {F : Set Î±} {A : Set F} (c : (S.induce F).coe.IsClique A) :
```
for dot notation

```suggestion
  exact âŸ¨cc.left.of_induce, cc.rightâŸ©
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] -  feat(Combinatorics/SimpleGraph): Add a theorem about cliques in induced subgraphs
